name: Introduction to Matter and Its Properties
short_description: Students explore the definition of matter, learn to distinguish between physical and chemical properties, and classify matter based on observable characteristics. This foundational topic establishes understanding of how scientists describe and categorize substances.

sub_topics.name: Definition and Characteristics of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn that matter is anything that has mass and takes up space, and explore examples and non-examples of matter.

sub_topics.name: What is Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that matter has mass and volume, and identifying examples of matter in everyday life.
example_tasks: List five examples of matter found in your classroom and explain why each qualifies as matter.
Determine which of the following are matter: air, light, sound, water, heat. Justify your answers.
Design an experiment to demonstrate that air is matter by showing it has mass and takes up space.

sub_topics.name: Mass and Volume
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring and comparing the mass and volume of different materials using appropriate tools and units.
example_tasks: Measure the mass of three different objects using a balance and record your results in grams.
Calculate the volume of a rectangular solid using the formula V = l × w × h given measurements in centimeters.
Compare the mass and volume of equal-sized samples of aluminum and iron, and explain what this tells you about the materials.

sub_topics.name: States of Matter Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing the three common states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas.
example_tasks: Classify the following substances by their state at room temperature: water, oxygen, iron, milk, carbon dioxide.
Describe the shape and volume characteristics that distinguish solids, liquids, and gases.
Observe an ice cube melting and then the water evaporating. Identify the states of matter present at each stage.

sub_topics.name: Physical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Students identify and measure physical properties that can be observed or measured without changing the substance's identity.

sub_topics.name: Observable Physical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying properties such as color, texture, hardness, and state that can be observed without chemical change.
example_tasks: Create a data table describing the color, texture, and state of five different materials in your home.
Use the Mohs hardness scale to compare the hardness of several minerals by performing scratch tests.
Examine samples of copper, sulfur, and graphite. Record their physical properties including luster, color, and texture.

sub_topics.name: Measurable Physical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring properties such as mass, volume, density, melting point, and boiling point using appropriate instruments.
example_tasks: Measure the mass and volume of a wooden block and calculate its density using the formula density = mass/volume.
Use a thermometer to determine the melting point of ice and the boiling point of water under normal atmospheric pressure.
Compare the densities of several liquids by carefully layering them in a graduated cylinder and observing which float or sink.

sub_topics.name: Density as a Characteristic Property
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding density as a ratio of mass to volume that is characteristic of a particular substance.
example_tasks: Given that aluminum has a density of 2.7 g/cm³, calculate the mass of an aluminum cube with a volume of 15 cm³.
Explain why a steel nail sinks in water but a large steel ship floats, using the concept of density.
Determine the identity of an unknown metal by calculating its density and comparing it to a reference table of metal densities.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore properties that describe how a substance changes into a different substance, requiring chemical reactions to observe.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Chemical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical properties describe a substance's ability to undergo chemical changes that produce new substances.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between observing that iron is gray (physical property) and observing that iron rusts (chemical property).
Identify which of the following are chemical properties: flammability, color, ability to react with acid, melting point.
Describe why the ability of wood to burn is considered a chemical property rather than a physical property.

sub_topics.name: Reactivity and Flammability
sub_topics.short_description: Observing how different substances react with other substances or burn in the presence of oxygen.
example_tasks: Compare the reactivity of magnesium ribbon and copper wire when placed in dilute hydrochloric acid.
Rank the following materials by flammability: paper, aluminum foil, wood, glass. Explain your reasoning.
Design a safe demonstration to show that some metals react with acids while others do not, producing different evidence of reaction.

sub_topics.name: Distinguishing Physical and Chemical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing the skill of categorizing properties as physical or chemical based on whether the substance's identity changes.
example_tasks: Create a two-column table listing five physical properties and five chemical properties of common materials.
Explain whether each of the following observations describes a physical or chemical property: water freezes at 0°C; sodium reacts violently with water; gold is shiny.
For a candle, list three physical properties you can observe without burning it and two chemical properties revealed when it burns.

sub_topics.name: Classification of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to categorize matter as pure substances or mixtures, and further classify pure substances as elements or compounds.

sub_topics.name: Pure Substances vs. Mixtures
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between matter with uniform composition (pure substances) and matter containing two or more substances (mixtures).
example_tasks: Classify each of the following as a pure substance or mixture: salt water, pure water, air, gold, soil.
Explain why distilled water is a pure substance but tap water is a mixture.
Design an investigation to determine whether a clear liquid is a pure substance or a mixture containing dissolved substances.

sub_topics.name: Elements and Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that elements contain only one type of atom while compounds contain two or more types of atoms chemically bonded.
example_tasks: Identify which of the following are elements: water (H₂O), oxygen (O₂), carbon dioxide (CO₂), gold (Au), table salt (NaCl).
Explain why water is classified as a compound even though it is a pure substance.
Using the periodic table, identify five elements and describe how compounds differ from elements in terms of atomic composition.

sub_topics.name: Homogeneous and Heterogeneous Mixtures
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between mixtures with uniform composition throughout (homogeneous) and those with visibly different parts (heterogeneous).
example_tasks: Classify the following as homogeneous or heterogeneous mixtures: saltwater, trail mix, air, chicken noodle soup, brass alloy.
Prepare a homogeneous mixture by dissolving sugar in water and a heterogeneous mixture by combining sand and iron filings.
Explain why milk appears to be a homogeneous mixture but is actually a heterogeneous mixture called a colloid when viewed under a microscope.

name: Atomic Structure and the Periodic Table
short_description: Students develop understanding of atoms as the fundamental building blocks of matter, explore atomic structure, and learn how the periodic table organizes elements based on their properties. This topic connects the microscopic world of atoms to the macroscopic properties of materials.

sub_topics.name: Development of Atomic Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the historical development of atomic models from Democritus to modern quantum theory.

sub_topics.name: Early Atomic Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding early philosophical ideas about atoms and the development of Dalton's atomic theory.
example_tasks: Describe Democritus's idea that matter is made of indivisible particles called atoms and explain why this was only a philosophical idea, not a scientific theory.
List the main points of John Dalton's atomic theory and explain which points are still accepted today.
Compare how Dalton's atomic theory explained the law of conservation of mass and the law of definite proportions.

sub_topics.name: Discovery of Subatomic Particles
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about the discovery of electrons, protons, and neutrons, and how these discoveries changed atomic models.
example_tasks: Explain how J.J. Thomson's cathode ray tube experiments led to the discovery of the electron and his 'plum pudding' model of the atom.
Describe Rutherford's gold foil experiment and explain how the results led to the discovery of the nucleus.
Create a timeline showing the discovery of the electron (1897), proton (1911), and neutron (1932).

sub_topics.name: Modern Atomic Model
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the Bohr model and the modern electron cloud model of the atom.
example_tasks: Draw and label a Bohr model of an oxygen atom showing the nucleus and electrons in energy levels.
Explain how the modern electron cloud model differs from Bohr's model in terms of where electrons are located.
Compare the sizes of the nucleus and the electron cloud, and explain why atoms are mostly empty space.

sub_topics.name: Structure of Atoms
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn about protons, neutrons, and electrons, and how they determine an element's identity and properties.

sub_topics.name: Subatomic Particles and Their Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the location, charge, and relative mass of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
example_tasks: Create a table comparing protons, neutrons, and electrons in terms of location in the atom, electrical charge, and relative mass.
Explain why the number of protons determines an element's identity while the number of neutrons can vary.
Calculate the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons in an atom of carbon-12, given that it has a mass number of 12 and atomic number of 6.

sub_topics.name: Atomic Number and Mass Number
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atomic number equals the number of protons and mass number equals protons plus neutrons.
example_tasks: Given that sodium has an atomic number of 11 and a mass number of 23, determine the number of protons, electrons, and neutrons.
Explain why all atoms of the same element have the same atomic number but may have different mass numbers.
Use the periodic table to find the atomic number of chlorine and determine how many protons and electrons are in a neutral chlorine atom.

sub_topics.name: Isotopes
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons and different mass numbers.
example_tasks: Compare carbon-12 and carbon-14 in terms of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Explain why both are called carbon.
Calculate the number of neutrons in three isotopes of hydrogen: hydrogen-1, hydrogen-2 (deuterium), and hydrogen-3 (tritium).
Explain why isotopes of an element have the same chemical properties but may have different physical properties like density.

sub_topics.name: Average Atomic Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the atomic mass on the periodic table is a weighted average of all naturally occurring isotopes.
example_tasks: Explain why the atomic mass of chlorine (35.45 amu) is not a whole number, given that it has isotopes chlorine-35 and chlorine-37.
If an element has two isotopes, one with mass 10 amu (20% abundance) and one with mass 11 amu (80% abundance), calculate the average atomic mass.
Use the periodic table to find the average atomic mass of carbon and explain what this number represents.

sub_topics.name: Organization of the Periodic Table
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore how elements are organized by increasing atomic number and repeating patterns of properties.

sub_topics.name: Structure of the Periodic Table
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the arrangement of periods (rows) and groups (columns) and what they represent.
example_tasks: Identify the period and group number for the element sodium (Na) on the periodic table.
Explain why elements in the same group (column) have similar chemical properties.
Locate the metals, nonmetals, and metalloids on a blank periodic table and describe the general location of each category.

sub_topics.name: Families of Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about groups with special names and similar properties: alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, halogens, noble gases.
example_tasks: List three elements from the alkali metal family (Group 1) and describe their common properties, such as reactivity with water.
Explain why noble gases (Group 18) are called 'inert' or 'unreactive' and give three examples.
Compare the reactivity of fluorine, chlorine, and bromine (all halogens) and predict which is most reactive based on periodic trends.

sub_topics.name: Metals, Nonmetals, and Metalloids
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying elements based on their physical and chemical properties as metals, nonmetals, or metalloids.
example_tasks: Create a Venn diagram comparing the properties of metals and nonmetals, including conductivity, malleability, and luster.
Identify silicon and germanium as metalloids and explain why they are useful in the electronics industry.
Given a list of elements (iron, sulfur, oxygen, copper, carbon), classify each as a metal, nonmetal, or metalloid and justify your classification.

sub_topics.name: Periodic Trends
sub_topics.short_description: Observing patterns in atomic size, reactivity, and other properties as you move across periods and down groups.
example_tasks: Explain why atomic size generally decreases from left to right across a period on the periodic table.
Predict which element has a larger atomic radius: sodium or magnesium. Explain your reasoning using periodic trends.
Compare the reactivity of lithium and cesium (both Group 1 metals) and explain why cesium is more reactive based on its position on the periodic table.

sub_topics.name: Electron Configuration Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how electrons are arranged in energy levels and how this arrangement affects chemical properties.

sub_topics.name: Energy Levels and Shells
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that electrons occupy specific energy levels around the nucleus, with each level holding a maximum number of electrons.
example_tasks: Draw a Bohr model for an atom of neon (atomic number 10) showing the correct distribution of electrons in energy levels.
State the maximum number of electrons that can occupy the first, second, and third energy levels (2, 8, 8 for first three levels in simplified model).
Explain why sodium (11 electrons) has one electron in its outermost energy level, making it highly reactive.

sub_topics.name: Valence Electrons
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the electrons in the outermost energy level and understanding their importance in chemical bonding.
example_tasks: Determine the number of valence electrons for elements in Groups 1, 2, 13-18 using their group number.
Explain why elements in the same group have similar chemical properties by comparing their valence electron configurations.
Draw electron dot diagrams (Lewis dot structures) for the elements in the second period (Li through Ne).

sub_topics.name: Stable Electron Configurations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atoms are most stable when they have a full outer energy level, like the noble gases.
example_tasks: Explain why noble gases are unreactive by examining the electron configuration of helium (2 electrons) and neon (8 valence electrons).
Predict whether chlorine will tend to gain or lose electrons to achieve a stable electron configuration, and explain your reasoning.
Describe the 'octet rule' and explain why atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve eight valence electrons.

name: Pure Substances and Mixtures
short_description: Students investigate the differences between pure substances (elements and compounds) and mixtures, and learn techniques for separating mixtures based on physical properties. This topic emphasizes the physical processes used to isolate components without changing their chemical identity.

sub_topics.name: Elements in Detail
sub_topics.short_description: Students develop deeper understanding of elements as pure substances containing only one type of atom.

sub_topics.name: Naturally Occurring Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying elements that occur in nature and understanding their distribution in Earth's crust, oceans, and atmosphere.
example_tasks: List the five most abundant elements in Earth's crust (oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, calcium) and explain their importance.
Research which elements exist as free elements in nature (like gold, sulfur, carbon as graphite) and which are only found in compounds.
Explain why oxygen and nitrogen make up most of Earth's atmosphere, and identify the percentage of each gas.

sub_topics.name: Synthetic Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about elements that do not occur naturally and must be created in laboratories or particle accelerators.
example_tasks: Identify where synthetic elements appear on the periodic table (generally beyond atomic number 92).
Explain why synthetic elements are unstable and often exist for only fractions of a second.
Research one synthetic element (such as plutonium or americium) and describe a practical application or research use.

sub_topics.name: Diatomic Elements
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that some elements exist naturally as molecules containing two atoms bonded together.
example_tasks: Memorize the seven diatomic elements (H₂, N₂, O₂, F₂, Cl₂, Br₂, I₂) and explain why they exist as molecules rather than single atoms.
Write the correct formula for oxygen gas and explain why O₂ is different from O (a single oxygen atom).
Explain why noble gases exist as single atoms (monatomic) while most nonmetals are diatomic or form larger molecules.

sub_topics.name: Compounds in Detail
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore compounds as pure substances formed when two or more elements chemically combine in fixed ratios.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that compounds have properties different from the elements that form them.
example_tasks: Compare the properties of sodium (a soft, reactive metal) and chlorine (a toxic gas) with sodium chloride (table salt, a stable compound).
Explain why water (H₂O) has completely different properties from hydrogen gas and oxygen gas.
Demonstrate that compounds have fixed composition by showing that water always contains hydrogen and oxygen in a 2:1 ratio.

sub_topics.name: Chemical vs. Physical Combinations
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between chemical compounds (where elements bond and form new substances) and mixtures (where substances are physically combined).
example_tasks: Compare mixing iron filings with sulfur (physical combination) versus heating them together to form iron sulfide (chemical combination).
Explain why you can use a magnet to separate iron from a mixture of iron and sulfur, but not from the compound iron sulfide.
Describe three pieces of evidence that show a chemical compound has formed rather than just a mixture: new properties, energy change, inability to easily separate.

sub_topics.name: Molecular and Ionic Compounds Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that compounds can be classified as molecular (sharing electrons) or ionic (transferring electrons).
example_tasks: Identify whether the following compounds are molecular or ionic: water (H₂O), table salt (NaCl), carbon dioxide (CO₂), magnesium oxide (MgO).
Explain why ionic compounds typically form between metals and nonmetals, while molecular compounds form between nonmetals.
Compare the general properties of ionic compounds (high melting points, conduct electricity when dissolved) with molecular compounds (lower melting points, poor conductors).

sub_topics.name: Types of Mixtures
sub_topics.short_description: Students classify and analyze different types of mixtures based on particle size and uniformity.

sub_topics.name: Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding solutions as homogeneous mixtures where one substance (solute) is dissolved in another (solvent).
example_tasks: Identify the solute and solvent in the following solutions: salt water, vinegar (acetic acid in water), brass (zinc in copper).
Prepare three different concentrations of sugar water and explain how the amount of solute affects the solution's properties.
Explain why air is a solution (nitrogen and oxygen gases mixed uniformly) and give two other examples of gaseous solutions.

sub_topics.name: Suspensions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning about heterogeneous mixtures where particles are large enough to settle out or be filtered.
example_tasks: Observe muddy water settling and explain why this is a suspension rather than a solution.
Design an investigation to demonstrate that suspensions can be separated by filtration, while solutions cannot.
Give three examples of suspensions in everyday life (e.g., orange juice with pulp, snow globe liquid, Italian salad dressing).

sub_topics.name: Colloids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding colloids as mixtures with intermediate particle sizes that do not settle but scatter light (Tyndall effect).
example_tasks: Demonstrate the Tyndall effect by shining a flashlight through a colloid (milk) and a solution (salt water), comparing the light scattering.
Explain why fog, smoke, and mayonnaise are classified as colloids rather than solutions or suspensions.
Classify the following as solutions, suspensions, or colloids: gelatin, muddy water, sugar water, milk, sand in water.

sub_topics.name: Separation Techniques
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn physical methods to separate mixture components based on different properties without changing chemical identities.

sub_topics.name: Filtration
sub_topics.short_description: Using physical barriers to separate solids from liquids or gases based on particle size.
example_tasks: Design and perform an experiment to separate a mixture of sand and water using filter paper and a funnel.
Explain why filtration can separate a suspension but cannot separate a solution.
Describe how coffee filters, air filters in furnaces, and water treatment plants all use the principle of filtration.

sub_topics.name: Distillation
sub_topics.short_description: Separating components of a liquid mixture based on different boiling points through evaporation and condensation.
example_tasks: Draw and label a diagram of a simple distillation apparatus showing the heat source, distillation flask, condenser, and collection flask.
Explain how distillation could be used to obtain pure water from salt water, and describe what happens to the salt.
Describe how fractional distillation is used in petroleum refineries to separate crude oil into gasoline, kerosene, and other products.

sub_topics.name: Chromatography
sub_topics.short_description: Separating dissolved substances based on different rates of movement through a medium.
example_tasks: Perform paper chromatography to separate the different pigments in black ink using a solvent like water or rubbing alcohol.
Explain how chromatography separates mixtures based on the different attractions between substances and the paper or solvent.
Analyze a chromatogram and identify how many different components were present in the original mixture based on the number of separated bands.

sub_topics.name: Evaporation and Crystallization
sub_topics.short_description: Separating dissolved solids from liquids by evaporating the solvent, leaving crystals behind.
example_tasks: Design an experiment to recover salt from salt water by evaporation, and calculate the percent recovery.
Explain the difference between evaporation (removing solvent) and crystallization (forming pure crystals by controlled cooling).
Describe how sea salt is produced commercially through solar evaporation of seawater.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Separation
sub_topics.short_description: Using magnets to separate magnetic materials from non-magnetic materials in a mixture.
example_tasks: Demonstrate magnetic separation by removing iron filings from a mixture of iron filings and sand using a magnet.
Explain why magnetic separation works for some mixtures (iron and sulfur) but not for others (salt and sugar).
Describe how magnetic separation is used in recycling facilities to separate steel and iron from other materials.

name: Chemical and Physical Changes
short_description: Students learn to distinguish between physical changes (where the substance's identity remains the same) and chemical changes (where new substances form). This topic emphasizes recognizing evidence of chemical reactions and understanding conservation of mass.

sub_topics.name: Physical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Students identify changes in form, state, or appearance where the chemical composition remains unchanged.

sub_topics.name: Changes in State
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation, and sublimation are physical changes.
example_tasks: Observe ice melting into water and then evaporating, and explain why these are physical changes even though the appearance changes dramatically.
Create a diagram showing all six phase changes (melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation, sublimation, deposition) with examples of each.
Explain why dry ice (solid CO₂) subliming directly to gas is a physical change rather than a chemical change.

sub_topics.name: Changes in Shape or Form
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that cutting, crushing, bending, or reshaping materials are physical changes.
example_tasks: Explain why cutting a piece of paper into smaller pieces is a physical change by describing what happens to the paper's chemical composition.
Demonstrate that dissolving sugar in water is a physical change by evaporating the water to recover the sugar crystals.
Compare crushing ice into snow with burning wood, and explain which is a physical change and which is a chemical change.

sub_topics.name: Reversibility of Physical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that many physical changes can be reversed to restore the original substance.
example_tasks: Demonstrate the reversibility of freezing water by melting the ice back into liquid water.
Explain why physical changes are generally easier to reverse than chemical changes, using examples like dissolving vs. burning.
Describe a physical change that is difficult to reverse (like mixing salt and pepper) and explain why it's still physical despite being hard to undo.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Changes and Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students identify chemical changes where new substances with different properties are formed through chemical reactions.

sub_topics.name: Evidence of Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing signs that indicate a chemical reaction has occurred: color change, gas production, precipitate formation, energy change.
example_tasks: Observe a mixture of baking soda and vinegar and identify at least three pieces of evidence that a chemical reaction occurred (bubbling, temperature change, new substance formed).
Explain why the production of a gas (bubbles) during a reaction is evidence of a chemical change, using the example of an antacid tablet in water.
Design an investigation to test whether rusting of iron is a chemical change by looking for evidence such as color change and formation of a new substance.

sub_topics.name: Examples of Chemical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common chemical changes including combustion, oxidation, decomposition, and synthesis reactions.
example_tasks: List five examples of chemical changes from everyday life (e.g., burning wood, cooking an egg, digesting food, tarnishing silver, photosynthesis).
Compare burning a candle with melting a candle, and explain which is a chemical change and which is physical.
Observe a piece of apple turning brown after being cut, and explain why this oxidation is a chemical change.

sub_topics.name: Irreversibility of Chemical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical changes typically cannot be easily reversed because new substances have formed.
example_tasks: Explain why you cannot 'unburn' wood to get back the original log, using your understanding of chemical changes.
Compare the ease of reversing a physical change (melting ice) with reversing a chemical change (baking a cake).
Describe why chemical changes often require significant energy input to reverse, if reversal is even possible.

sub_topics.name: Energy in Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Observing that chemical reactions involve energy changes, either releasing energy (exothermic) or absorbing energy (endothermic).
example_tasks: Identify whether the following reactions are exothermic or endothermic: burning wood, photosynthesis, hand warmer activating, ice pack getting cold.
Measure the temperature change when vinegar and baking soda react, and determine whether the reaction is exothermic or endothermic.
Explain why some chemical reactions (like combustion) release heat and light, using the concept of chemical energy stored in bonds.

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Students investigate that mass is conserved in both physical and chemical changes, and learn to account for all substances involved.

sub_topics.name: Law of Conservation of Mass
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that matter is neither created nor destroyed in chemical reactions; atoms are rearranged but not lost or gained.
example_tasks: State the law of conservation of mass and explain what it means in terms of atoms during a chemical reaction.
Predict what will happen to the total mass of a sealed container when a chemical reaction occurs inside it.
Explain why Antoine Lavoisier is credited with discovering the law of conservation of mass through careful measurements in closed systems.

sub_topics.name: Closed vs. Open Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that mass appears to change in open systems when gases escape or are absorbed, but is actually conserved.
example_tasks: Design an experiment to demonstrate conservation of mass by conducting a reaction (baking soda and vinegar) in both an open beaker and a closed plastic bag.
Explain why burning wood in air appears to lose mass (because gases escape) but actually follows conservation of mass.
Describe why rusting iron appears to gain mass (absorbing oxygen from air) and explain how this demonstrates conservation when you account for all reactants.

sub_topics.name: Measuring Mass in Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing careful measurement techniques to verify that total mass before a reaction equals total mass after the reaction.
example_tasks: Measure the combined mass of reactants before mixing, allow them to react in a closed system, then measure the mass of products to verify conservation.
Explain why you must account for all reactants (including gases from air) and all products (including escaped gases) when verifying conservation of mass.
Calculate the expected mass of products if 10 g of reactant A combines completely with 15 g of reactant B, assuming no mass is lost to the surroundings.

sub_topics.name: Accounting for All Substances
sub_topics.short_description: Developing skills to identify all reactants and products, including those that may be invisible gases.
example_tasks: When vinegar and baking soda react, identify all products formed (including the carbon dioxide gas) and explain how to capture and measure the gas to verify conservation of mass.
Explain why burning a candle in a closed jar eventually stops burning, and account for all substances present before and after.
Design an investigation to show that when steel wool rusts, the mass increase equals the mass of oxygen absorbed from the air.

sub_topics.name: Comparing Physical and Chemical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Students practice distinguishing between physical and chemical changes through observation and analysis.

sub_topics.name: Identification Strategies
sub_topics.short_description: Developing systematic approaches to determine whether a change is physical or chemical.
example_tasks: Create a decision tree or flowchart to help determine whether an observed change is physical or chemical.
Analyze the following scenario: ice cream melting on a hot day. Identify the type of change and justify your answer with specific criteria.
Examine a piece of iron before and after rusting, testing properties like magnetism and color, to confirm a chemical change has occurred.

sub_topics.name: Ambiguous Cases
sub_topics.short_description: Investigating changes that may appear to be one type but are actually the other, or involve both types of changes.
example_tasks: Explain why dissolving is typically a physical change, but sometimes involves chemical changes (like dissolving an antacid tablet).
Analyze what happens when you cook an egg: identify which parts are physical changes (heat transfer) and which are chemical (protein denaturation).
Investigate whether burning a candle involves only chemical changes or both physical (wax melting) and chemical (wax burning) changes.

sub_topics.name: Practical Applications
sub_topics.short_description: Applying understanding of physical and chemical changes to real-world situations and technologies.
example_tasks: Explain how understanding physical vs. chemical changes helps in recycling, where physical changes (melting aluminum) are easier than reversing chemical changes (breaking down plastics).
Describe how food preservation methods use both physical changes (freezing) and prevention of chemical changes (spoilage reactions).
Analyze the processes involved in making concrete: physical changes (mixing) and chemical changes (hardening through hydration reactions).

name: Chemical Bonding Fundamentals
short_description: Students explore how atoms form bonds to achieve stable electron configurations, learning about ionic bonds (electron transfer) and covalent bonds (electron sharing). This topic connects atomic structure to the formation of compounds and explains why elements combine in specific ratios.

sub_topics.name: Why Atoms Bond
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atoms bond to achieve stable electron configurations, typically completing their outer energy level.

sub_topics.name: Achieving Stability
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that atoms are most stable when they have full outer energy levels like the noble gases.
example_tasks: Explain why sodium (with one valence electron) is highly reactive while neon (with eight valence electrons) is unreactive.
Draw electron dot diagrams for helium and argon, and explain why these noble gases do not typically form bonds.
Predict whether each of the following elements will tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve stability: fluorine, magnesium, carbon.

sub_topics.name: The Octet Rule
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve eight valence electrons (except hydrogen and helium, which need two).
example_tasks: State the octet rule and explain why it applies to most elements but not to hydrogen and helium.
Use the octet rule to predict how many electrons chlorine needs to gain to achieve a stable configuration.
Explain why carbon typically forms four bonds by examining its four valence electrons and the octet rule.

sub_topics.name: Electronegativity Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that electronegativity describes an atom's ability to attract electrons in a bond, affecting bond type.
example_tasks: Define electronegativity and explain how it differs from electron affinity.
Identify which element has higher electronegativity in each pair: oxygen vs. nitrogen, fluorine vs. chlorine, carbon vs. hydrogen.
Explain how differences in electronegativity between two atoms help predict whether they will form ionic or covalent bonds.

sub_topics.name: Ionic Bonding
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn that ionic bonds form when electrons transfer from metal atoms to nonmetal atoms, creating oppositely charged ions that attract.

sub_topics.name: Formation of Ions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how atoms become cations (by losing electrons) or anions (by gaining electrons).
example_tasks: Draw diagrams showing how sodium loses one electron to become Na⁺ and how chlorine gains one electron to become Cl⁻.
Predict the charge on ions formed by elements in Groups 1, 2, 16, and 17 based on their valence electrons.
Explain why metals tend to form cations while nonmetals tend to form anions, using electronegativity and energy considerations.

sub_topics.name: Electrostatic Attraction
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that ionic bonds result from the strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions.
example_tasks: Explain why Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions strongly attract each other to form sodium chloride.
Describe the crystal lattice structure of ionic compounds, where each ion is surrounded by oppositely charged ions.
Use Coulomb's law concepts to explain why ionic compounds with ions of higher charge (like Mg²⁺ and O²⁻) have stronger attractions and higher melting points.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Ionic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding characteristic properties: high melting/boiling points, brittle, conduct electricity when dissolved or molten.
example_tasks: Explain why ionic compounds like table salt have high melting points compared to molecular compounds like sugar.
Demonstrate that solid sodium chloride does not conduct electricity, but when dissolved in water it does. Explain why in terms of ion movement.
Describe why ionic compounds are brittle and shatter when struck, using the concept of like-charged ions repelling when layers shift.

sub_topics.name: Writing Ionic Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to determine the correct ratio of ions in ionic compounds so that total positive charge equals total negative charge.
example_tasks: Write the formula for the ionic compound formed between magnesium (Mg²⁺) and chlorine (Cl⁻), explaining why two chloride ions are needed.
Determine the formula for aluminum oxide, given that aluminum forms Al³⁺ ions and oxygen forms O²⁻ ions.
Use the crisscross method to write formulas for ionic compounds: calcium fluoride, sodium oxide, aluminum sulfide.

sub_topics.name: Covalent Bonding
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore how atoms share electrons to form covalent bonds, typically between nonmetal atoms.

sub_topics.name: Electron Sharing
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that covalent bonds form when atoms share pairs of electrons to satisfy the octet rule.
example_tasks: Draw a diagram showing how two hydrogen atoms share electrons to form H₂, each achieving a filled outer level (two electrons).
Explain why two oxygen atoms share two pairs of electrons (forming a double bond) in O₂ to each achieve an octet.
Describe the difference between bonding electrons (shared between atoms) and lone pairs (not involved in bonding).

sub_topics.name: Single, Double, and Triple Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that atoms can share one, two, or three pairs of electrons, forming single, double, or triple bonds.
example_tasks: Draw Lewis dot structures for H₂ (single bond), O₂ (double bond), and N₂ (triple bond).
Explain why nitrogen atoms in N₂ share three pairs of electrons (triple bond) to each achieve eight valence electrons.
Compare the bond strength and bond length of single, double, and triple bonds, noting that triple bonds are shortest and strongest.

sub_topics.name: Properties of Covalent Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding characteristic properties: lower melting/boiling points, do not conduct electricity, exist as molecules.
example_tasks: Explain why water (covalent compound) has a much lower boiling point than sodium chloride (ionic compound).
Describe why sugar (covalent) dissolves in water but does not conduct electricity, unlike salt (ionic) which does conduct when dissolved.
Compare the hardness and brittleness of diamond (network covalent) with typical molecular covalent compounds like wax.

sub_topics.name: Lewis Dot Structures
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing drawing Lewis structures to represent bonding and lone pair electrons in molecules.
example_tasks: Draw Lewis dot structures for simple molecules: H₂O, NH₃, CH₄, CO₂.
Use Lewis structures to show all bonding pairs and lone pairs of electrons in HCl and F₂.
Predict the number of bonds an atom will typically form based on its valence electrons: hydrogen (1), oxygen (2), nitrogen (3), carbon (4).

sub_topics.name: Comparing Bond Types
sub_topics.short_description: Students compare and contrast ionic and covalent bonding, learning to predict bond type based on element properties.

sub_topics.name: Metallic Bonding Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Brief introduction to metallic bonding where electrons are delocalized among metal atoms.
example_tasks: Describe the 'sea of electrons' model of metallic bonding, where valence electrons move freely among metal cations.
Explain how metallic bonding accounts for properties of metals: electrical conductivity, malleability, and luster.
Compare the three types of chemical bonds: ionic (electron transfer), covalent (electron sharing), and metallic (electron delocalization).

sub_topics.name: Predicting Bond Type
sub_topics.short_description: Using electronegativity differences and element types to predict whether a bond will be ionic or covalent.
example_tasks: Predict the bond type for each pair of elements: Na and Cl (ionic), C and O (covalent), Cu and Cu (metallic).
Use the rule that bonds between metals and nonmetals are typically ionic, while bonds between nonmetals are covalent, to classify several compounds.
Explain how large electronegativity differences (>1.7) generally indicate ionic bonding, while smaller differences indicate covalent bonding.

sub_topics.name: Polar vs. Nonpolar Covalent Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that unequal sharing of electrons creates polar covalent bonds, while equal sharing creates nonpolar bonds.
example_tasks: Explain why the H-Cl bond is polar covalent (chlorine attracts electrons more strongly) while H-H is nonpolar (equal sharing).
Use electronegativity values to determine whether bonds are nonpolar covalent, polar covalent, or ionic.
Draw a molecule of water (H₂O) and use arrows (δ⁺ and δ⁻) to show the partial charges resulting from polar O-H bonds.

sub_topics.name: Properties Comparison
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing physical and chemical properties of ionic, covalent, and metallic substances.
example_tasks: Create a comparison table showing melting point, electrical conductivity, solubility in water, and hardness for ionic, covalent, and metallic substances.
Explain why metals conduct electricity in solid form but ionic compounds only conduct when melted or dissolved.
Given a substance's properties (high melting point, conducts when dissolved, brittle), predict whether it is ionic, covalent, or metallic.

name: Chemical Formulas and Nomenclature
short_description: Students learn to write chemical formulas for compounds and name them using systematic nomenclature rules. This topic develops skills in translating between names, formulas, and molecular representations of substances.

sub_topics.name: Writing Chemical Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to represent compounds using chemical symbols and subscripts that show the ratio of atoms.

sub_topics.name: Molecular Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Writing formulas that show the actual number of each type of atom in a molecule.
example_tasks: Write molecular formulas for water (H₂O), carbon dioxide (CO₂), and glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆).
Explain what the subscripts in a formula represent, using H₂SO₄ as an example (2 hydrogen, 1 sulfur, 4 oxygen atoms).
Count the total number of atoms in one molecule of: NH₃, C₂H₆, Ca(OH)₂.

sub_topics.name: Empirical Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that empirical formulas show the simplest whole-number ratio of atoms in a compound.
example_tasks: Determine the empirical formula for glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) by reducing to the simplest ratio (CH₂O).
Explain the difference between molecular formula (actual numbers) and empirical formula (simplest ratio).
Given that a compound contains 2 carbon atoms and 6 hydrogen atoms, write both its molecular formula (C₂H₆) and empirical formula (CH₃).

sub_topics.name: Formula Units for Ionic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Writing formulas for ionic compounds that show the ratio of ions in the crystal lattice.
example_tasks: Write the formula for sodium chloride (NaCl) and explain why no subscript is needed when the ratio is 1:1.
Determine the formula for magnesium chloride, showing why two chloride ions are needed for each magnesium ion (MgCl₂).
Write formulas for: calcium oxide, aluminum bromide, sodium sulfide, using correct ion charges.

sub_topics.name: Polyatomic Ions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to recognize and write formulas for compounds containing polyatomic ions like sulfate, nitrate, and carbonate.
example_tasks: Write the formula for sodium sulfate, showing the correct use of parentheses: Na₂SO₄.
Determine the formula for calcium nitrate, explaining why it is Ca(NO₃)₂ rather than CaNO₃.
Memorize common polyatomic ions and write formulas for: ammonium chloride, potassium carbonate, sodium hydroxide, calcium phosphate.

sub_topics.name: Naming Ionic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn systematic rules for naming binary ionic compounds and those with polyatomic ions.

sub_topics.name: Binary Ionic Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Naming compounds with one metal and one nonmetal: metal name + nonmetal root + '-ide'.
example_tasks: Name the following binary ionic compounds: NaCl (sodium chloride), MgO (magnesium oxide), AlBr₃ (aluminum bromide).
Write formulas for: potassium iodide, calcium fluoride, lithium oxide.
Explain the naming pattern for binary ionic compounds and why the nonmetal ending changes to '-ide'.

sub_topics.name: Transition Metal Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Using Roman numerals to indicate the charge on transition metals that can form multiple ions.
example_tasks: Name FeCl₂ as iron(II) chloride and FeCl₃ as iron(III) chloride, explaining why Roman numerals are needed.
Determine the correct name for CuO (copper(II) oxide) and Cu₂O (copper(I) oxide) by analyzing the ion charges.
Write formulas for: iron(III) oxide, copper(I) sulfide, tin(IV) chloride.

sub_topics.name: Compounds with Polyatomic Ions
sub_topics.short_description: Naming ionic compounds that contain polyatomic ions like sulfate, nitrate, carbonate, and hydroxide.
example_tasks: Name the following compounds: Na₂SO₄ (sodium sulfate), Ca(NO₃)₂ (calcium nitrate), NH₄Cl (ammonium chloride).
Write formulas for: potassium carbonate, magnesium hydroxide, ammonium sulfate.
Explain why ammonium compounds (NH₄⁺) are ionic even though they don't contain a metal.

sub_topics.name: Naming Covalent Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to use Greek prefixes to name molecular compounds formed between nonmetals.

sub_topics.name: Using Greek Prefixes
sub_topics.short_description: Learning prefixes (mono-, di-, tri-, tetra-, penta-, etc.) to indicate the number of each atom in molecular compounds.
example_tasks: Name CO₂ as carbon dioxide and CO as carbon monoxide, noting that 'mono-' is usually omitted for the first element.
Write the name for N₂O₄ (dinitrogen tetroxide) using the appropriate Greek prefixes.
Name the following molecular compounds: SO₃, PCl₅, N₂O, CCl₄.

sub_topics.name: Writing Formulas from Names
sub_topics.short_description: Translating systematic names with Greek prefixes back into chemical formulas.
example_tasks: Write formulas for: sulfur hexafluoride, dinitrogen pentoxide, carbon tetrachloride.
Explain how the prefixes in 'tetraphosphorus decoxide' tell you the formula is P₄O₁₀.
Given the name 'dichlorine heptoxide', determine the formula (Cl₂O₇) and draw its Lewis structure.

sub_topics.name: Common Names vs. Systematic Names
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that some compounds have common names that differ from systematic names.
example_tasks: List common names and systematic names for: water (dihydrogen monoxide), ammonia (nitrogen trihydride), methane (not typically given a systematic name).
Explain why H₂O is called 'water' rather than 'dihydrogen monoxide' in everyday contexts.
Identify which names are common and which are systematic: glucose, carbon dioxide, baking soda, sulfuric acid.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Formulas and Molecular Models
sub_topics.short_description: Students connect chemical formulas to three-dimensional molecular structures and models.

sub_topics.name: Ball-and-Stick Models
sub_topics.short_description: Using physical or computer models where atoms are represented as balls connected by sticks representing bonds.
example_tasks: Build or draw ball-and-stick models for H₂O, CH₄, and CO₂, showing the arrangement of atoms in space.
Explain what information a ball-and-stick model provides that a chemical formula alone does not (3D shape, bond angles).
Compare ball-and-stick models of O₂ (linear) and H₂O (bent) and explain why the shapes differ.

sub_topics.name: Space-Filling Models
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding models that show the relative sizes of atoms and how they occupy space in molecules.
example_tasks: Compare a ball-and-stick model of methane (CH₄) with a space-filling model and describe what each emphasizes.
Explain why space-filling models are useful for understanding how molecules interact and fit together.
Use space-filling models to visualize why large molecules like proteins have complex 3D shapes.

sub_topics.name: Structural Formulas
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing two-dimensional representations that show which atoms are bonded to which.
example_tasks: Draw structural formulas for water (H-O-H), ammonia (H₃N with H atoms bonded to N), and methane (central C with four H atoms).
Explain how structural formulas differ from molecular formulas by showing connectivity.
Convert molecular formulas to structural formulas for: H₂O₂, C₂H₆, CH₂O.

name: Chemical Reactions and Equations
short_description: Students learn to identify types of chemical reactions, write balanced chemical equations, and understand that equations represent the rearrangement of atoms. This topic emphasizes that atoms are conserved in reactions while molecules change.

sub_topics.name: Representing Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to write chemical equations using formulas, plus signs, and arrows to show reactants transforming into products.

sub_topics.name: Reactants and Products
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reactants are the starting substances (left side) and products are the substances formed (right side).
example_tasks: In the reaction of hydrogen and oxygen forming water (H₂ + O₂ → H₂O), identify the reactants and products.
Write a word equation for the combustion of methane: methane + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water.
Explain what the arrow in a chemical equation represents (reactants changing into products).

sub_topics.name: Chemical Equation Symbols
sub_topics.short_description: Using symbols to indicate states of matter: (s) solid, (l) liquid, (g) gas, (aq) aqueous solution.
example_tasks: Write the equation for dissolving salt in water: NaCl(s) → Na⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq).
Add state symbols to this equation: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H₂O (all in aqueous solution except water which is liquid).
Explain what (aq) means and why it's important to distinguish from (l) for water.

sub_topics.name: Energy in Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Indicating energy changes in reactions, showing whether energy is absorbed or released.
example_tasks: Write an equation for combustion showing that energy (heat and light) is released: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O + energy.
Indicate whether energy should appear on the reactant or product side for: burning wood (product), photosynthesis (reactant).
Explain why exothermic reactions release energy while endothermic reactions absorb energy, using specific examples.

sub_topics.name: Balancing Chemical Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to balance equations by adjusting coefficients to ensure equal numbers of each type of atom on both sides.

sub_topics.name: Law of Conservation Applied to Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that equations must be balanced because atoms are neither created nor destroyed in reactions.
example_tasks: Explain why the equation H₂ + O₂ → H₂O is not balanced and violates the law of conservation of mass.
Count atoms on each side of this unbalanced equation: N₂ + H₂ → NH₃, and determine why it needs balancing.
Describe what it means for an equation to be balanced in terms of atom count.

sub_topics.name: Using Coefficients
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that coefficients (whole numbers before formulas) are used to balance equations, never changing subscripts.
example_tasks: Balance the equation H₂ + O₂ → H₂O by placing a coefficient of 2 before H₂O: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.
Explain why you cannot balance equations by changing subscripts (which would change the substance's identity).
Practice using coefficients to balance: Mg + O₂ → MgO (answer: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO).

sub_topics.name: Systematic Balancing Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Developing strategies for balancing equations: starting with most complex molecules, balancing one element at a time.
example_tasks: Balance the combustion equation: C₃H₈ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O by balancing C, then H, then O.
Use the 'inspection method' to balance: Fe + Cl₂ → FeCl₃.
Balance more complex equations: Al + O₂ → Al₂O₃, CH₄ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O.

sub_topics.name: Checking Balanced Equations
sub_topics.short_description: Verifying that equations are balanced by counting atoms of each element on both sides.
example_tasks: Check whether this equation is balanced: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O by counting H atoms (4 on each side) and O atoms (2 on each side).
Identify the error in this equation: 2Fe + 3Cl₂ → 2FeCl₂ (should be FeCl₃).
Create a table to systematically check atom counts for a complex equation involving multiple elements.

sub_topics.name: Types of Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students classify reactions into categories: synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, double replacement, and combustion.

sub_topics.name: Synthesis (Combination) Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that synthesis reactions combine simpler substances to form a more complex product (A + B → AB).
example_tasks: Identify the pattern in synthesis reactions and give the general form: A + B → AB.
Write and balance equations for synthesis reactions: 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO; 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.
Predict the product of combining sodium and chlorine: 2Na + Cl₂ → 2NaCl.

sub_topics.name: Decomposition Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that decomposition reactions break down complex substances into simpler products (AB → A + B).
example_tasks: Write the general form of decomposition reactions: AB → A + B.
Balance the decomposition of water by electrolysis: 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂.
Predict the products when calcium carbonate decomposes with heat: CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂.

sub_topics.name: Single Replacement Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that a more reactive element replaces a less reactive element in a compound (A + BC → AC + B).
example_tasks: Write the general form: A + BC → AC + B (or A + BC → BA + C for nonmetal replacement).
Predict whether zinc will replace hydrogen in hydrochloric acid: Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂.
Explain why gold does not replace copper in copper sulfate (gold is less reactive than copper).

sub_topics.name: Double Replacement Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that ions in two compounds exchange places to form two new compounds (AB + CD → AD + CB).
example_tasks: Write the general form: AB + CD → AD + CB.
Predict products of mixing solutions: NaCl + AgNO₃ → NaNO₃ + AgCl (silver chloride precipitate forms).
Identify double replacement reactions by looking for precipitate formation, water formation, or gas production.

sub_topics.name: Combustion Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that combustion reactions involve rapid reaction with oxygen, producing oxides and releasing energy.
example_tasks: Write the general form for hydrocarbon combustion: CₓHᵧ + O₂ → CO₂ + H₂O + energy.
Balance combustion equations: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O; C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O.
Explain why combustion reactions are always exothermic and give examples from everyday life (burning wood, gasoline engines).

sub_topics.name: Predicting Reaction Products
sub_topics.short_description: Students develop skills to predict the products of reactions based on reactants and reaction type.

sub_topics.name: Using Reaction Patterns
sub_topics.short_description: Applying knowledge of reaction types to predict products systematically.
example_tasks: Given the reactants Mg + O₂, predict this is a synthesis reaction and the product is MgO.
Identify the reaction type and predict products: Fe + CuSO₄ → (single replacement: FeSO₄ + Cu).
For the reaction HCl + NaOH →, predict products of this double replacement: NaCl + H₂O.

sub_topics.name: Activity Series
sub_topics.short_description: Using the activity series to predict whether single replacement reactions will occur.
example_tasks: Use an activity series to determine if copper can replace silver in silver nitrate (yes, copper is more reactive).
Predict whether the reaction Ag + HCl → will occur (no, silver is below hydrogen in the activity series).
Explain how the activity series ranks metals by reactivity and how this helps predict single replacement reactions.

sub_topics.name: Solubility Rules
sub_topics.short_description: Using solubility rules to predict whether precipitates will form in double replacement reactions.
example_tasks: Apply solubility rules to predict that mixing NaCl and AgNO₃ produces a precipitate (AgCl is insoluble).
Determine whether a precipitate forms when solutions of KNO₃ and NaCl are mixed (no precipitate, both products are soluble).
Use solubility rules to predict which of these compounds are soluble in water: NaCl, AgCl, Ca(OH)₂, CaCO₃.

name: Conservation of Matter in Reactions
short_description: Students investigate the principle that atoms are rearranged but not created or destroyed in chemical reactions, developing quantitative understanding through balancing equations and analyzing mass relationships. This topic connects to the law of conservation of mass and stoichiometry basics.

sub_topics.name: Tracking Atoms in Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students practice following individual atoms through chemical reactions to verify conservation.

sub_topics.name: Atom Inventory
sub_topics.short_description: Counting atoms of each element in reactants and products to ensure they match.
example_tasks: For the reaction 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, create an inventory showing 4 H atoms and 2 O atoms on each side.
Count atoms in the combustion equation CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O: 1 C, 4 H, 4 O on each side.
Explain why an unbalanced equation violates conservation of atoms by showing different atom counts on each side.

sub_topics.name: Molecular Models of Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Using particle diagrams or models to visualize atoms rearranging during reactions.
example_tasks: Draw before-and-after particle diagrams for the reaction H₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl, showing how bonds break and new bonds form.
Use molecular models to demonstrate that in CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O, the total number of each type of atom is conserved.
Create a visual representation showing that burning 1 methane molecule and 2 oxygen molecules produces 1 carbon dioxide and 2 water molecules.

sub_topics.name: Rearrangement, Not Creation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical reactions involve breaking bonds in reactants and forming new bonds in products, rearranging atoms.
example_tasks: Explain why the reaction 2H₂O → 2H₂ + O₂ demonstrates atom rearrangement: bonds in water break and new bonds form in hydrogen and oxygen gas.
Describe what happens to atoms during combustion: they rearrange from fuel and oxygen molecules into carbon dioxide and water molecules.
Use the concept of bond breaking and forming to explain why mass is conserved in all chemical reactions.

sub_topics.name: Quantitative Relationships in Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore how coefficients in balanced equations represent mole ratios and mass relationships.

sub_topics.name: Coefficients and Ratios
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that coefficients show the ratio in which substances react and are produced.
example_tasks: In the equation 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, explain that 2 molecules of hydrogen react with 1 molecule of oxygen to produce 2 molecules of water.
Use coefficients to determine that in N₂ + 3H₂ → 2NH₃, 3 times as many hydrogen molecules as nitrogen molecules are needed.
Predict how many molecules of CO₂ are produced when 5 molecules of C₃H₈ burn: C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O (answer: 15 molecules CO₂).

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Stoichiometry
sub_topics.short_description: Basic introduction to using balanced equations to calculate amounts of reactants and products.
example_tasks: Given 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O, if you start with 4 hydrogen molecules, how many water molecules can you make (assuming excess oxygen)?
Explain how a balanced equation serves as a 'recipe' for a reaction, showing the proportions needed.
For the reaction 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO, predict how many magnesium oxide units form from 6 magnesium atoms (assuming excess oxygen).

sub_topics.name: Limiting Reactants Concept
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that the reactant in shortest supply limits the amount of product that can form.
example_tasks: In the reaction H₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl, if you have 3 H₂ molecules and 2 Cl₂ molecules, identify the limiting reactant (Cl₂) and calculate that 4 HCl molecules form.
Explain why the limiting reactant is like running out of one ingredient when baking: you can't make more product even if other ingredients remain.
For 2Mg + O₂ → 2MgO, if you have 5 Mg atoms and 2 O₂ molecules, determine how many MgO units can form (4) and which reactant is in excess (Mg).

sub_topics.name: Closed vs. Open Systems Revisited
sub_topics.short_description: Students investigate mass conservation in sealed containers versus reactions exposed to the atmosphere.

sub_topics.name: Designing Closed System Experiments
sub_topics.short_description: Planning investigations that contain all reactants and products to verify mass conservation.
example_tasks: Design an experiment to show conservation of mass by reacting baking soda and vinegar in a sealed plastic bag, weighing before and after.
Explain why conducting a reaction in a closed container is essential for demonstrating the law of conservation of mass.
Predict what will happen to the mass of a sealed flask when hydrogen and oxygen inside react to form water.

sub_topics.name: Accounting for Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gases have mass and must be included when verifying conservation of mass.
example_tasks: Explain why burning magnesium in an open container appears to gain mass (oxygen from air combines with magnesium).
Describe how to modify a combustion experiment to capture all products, including gaseous CO₂ and H₂O vapor, to verify mass conservation.
Calculate the mass of oxygen that combined with 10 g of magnesium if the product magnesium oxide has a mass of 16.6 g.

sub_topics.name: Real-World Applications of Conservation
sub_topics.short_description: Applying understanding of mass conservation to industrial processes, environmental science, and everyday phenomena.
example_tasks: Explain how understanding mass conservation helps engineers design efficient chemical manufacturing processes.
Describe how the law of conservation of mass applies to the carbon cycle, where carbon atoms cycle through atmosphere, plants, animals, and soil.
Analyze how conservation of mass is important in waste management: materials may change form but total mass remains constant.

sub_topics.name: Measuring and Calculating Mass Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Students practice experimental techniques and calculations to verify conservation of mass.

sub_topics.name: Precision in Measurement
sub_topics.short_description: Using balances accurately and recording measurements with appropriate precision.
example_tasks: Measure the mass of reactants before mixing to the nearest 0.01 g using a digital balance.
Explain why precise measurement is important for demonstrating conservation of mass in chemical reactions.
Identify sources of error in mass measurements (spillage, incomplete transfer, gas escape) and describe how to minimize them.

sub_topics.name: Percent Error Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating the difference between expected and measured masses to assess experimental accuracy.
example_tasks: If the initial mass of reactants was 50.0 g and the final mass after reaction was 49.8 g, calculate the percent error: |50.0-49.8|/50.0 × 100 = 0.4%.
Explain why small percent errors are expected in experiments due to measurement limitations and practical difficulties.
Analyze experimental results to determine whether observed mass changes are due to actual mass loss or measurement error.

sub_topics.name: Experimental Design Improvements
sub_topics.short_description: Modifying experiments to better demonstrate conservation of mass and reduce sources of error.
example_tasks: Propose improvements to an experiment where gas escaped: conduct the reaction in a sealed container or use a balloon to capture gas.
Design a better procedure for a reaction that produced a precipitate, ensuring all solid is collected and dried before weighing.
Explain how multiple trials and averaging results can improve the accuracy of conservation of mass demonstrations.

name: Energy and Chemical Reactions
short_description: Students explore the energy changes that accompany chemical reactions, learning to distinguish between exothermic reactions (releasing energy) and endothermic reactions (absorbing energy). This topic connects chemical processes to thermal energy transfer and conservation of energy.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Energy and Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical energy is stored in the bonds between atoms and is released or absorbed during reactions.

sub_topics.name: Energy Stored in Bonds
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that chemical bonds contain potential energy that can be released when bonds break and reform.
example_tasks: Explain why food, gasoline, and batteries all store chemical energy in their molecular bonds.
Describe how the energy stored in bonds between atoms is a form of potential energy.
Compare the energy stored in different fuels (wood, coal, gasoline) and explain why some fuels store more energy than others.

sub_topics.name: Bond Breaking and Forming
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that breaking bonds requires energy input while forming bonds releases energy.
example_tasks: Explain why energy is needed to break the bonds in reactant molecules before new bonds can form in product molecules.
Describe the energy changes during the reaction H₂ + Cl₂ → 2HCl: breaking H-H and Cl-Cl bonds (requires energy), forming H-Cl bonds (releases energy).
Draw a simple energy diagram showing that bond breaking is endothermic (requires energy) while bond forming is exothermic (releases energy).

sub_topics.name: Net Energy Change
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that the overall energy change depends on the difference between energy required to break bonds and energy released when new bonds form.
example_tasks: Explain why a reaction is exothermic if more energy is released in forming product bonds than is required to break reactant bonds.
Determine whether a reaction is endothermic or exothermic given: energy to break bonds = 500 kJ, energy released forming bonds = 700 kJ (exothermic, net release of 200 kJ).
Describe how the net energy change determines whether a reaction feels hot (exothermic) or cold (endothermic) to the touch.

sub_topics.name: Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students investigate reactions that release energy to the surroundings, typically as heat and sometimes as light.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying reactions that release energy, causing temperature increases in the surroundings.
example_tasks: Observe a hand warmer activating and explain why this exothermic reaction releases heat, making it feel warm.
List five examples of exothermic reactions: combustion, rusting, neutralization, cellular respiration, crystallization.

Measure the temperature change when vinegar and baking soda react, and determine if the reaction is exothermic or endothermic (slightly endothermic actually, but strong acids with bases are exothermic).

sub_topics.name: Combustion Reactions Detailed
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding combustion as rapid exothermic reactions with oxygen that release heat and light.
example_tasks: Explain why burning wood, gasoline, or natural gas releases both heat and light energy.
Write balanced equations for combustion reactions and indicate energy as a product: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O + energy.
Describe how combustion reactions are used in everyday life: heating homes, powering vehicles, generating electricity.

sub_topics.name: Energy Diagrams for Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing and interpreting diagrams that show energy decreasing from reactants to products.
example_tasks: Draw an energy diagram for an exothermic reaction showing that products have lower energy than reactants, with the difference released as heat.
Label the activation energy (energy needed to start the reaction) and the energy released on an exothermic reaction diagram.
Explain why the energy level of products is lower than reactants in exothermic reactions: energy has been released to the surroundings.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical uses of exothermic reactions in technology and daily life.
example_tasks: Describe how instant hot packs use exothermic crystallization of sodium acetate to provide heat for injuries.
Explain how rocket engines use highly exothermic combustion of fuel and oxidizer to produce thrust.
Research how self-heating food containers use exothermic reactions between quicklime and water to warm meals without external heat sources.

sub_topics.name: Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Students investigate reactions that absorb energy from the surroundings, typically causing temperature decreases.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying reactions that absorb energy, causing temperature decreases in the surroundings.
example_tasks: Observe an instant cold pack activating and explain why this endothermic process absorbs heat, making it feel cold.
List examples of endothermic processes: photosynthesis, melting ice, evaporation, dissolving ammonium nitrate, thermal decomposition.
Measure the temperature change when ammonium nitrate dissolves in water and explain why the solution gets colder (endothermic).

sub_topics.name: Photosynthesis as Endothermic Process
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that photosynthesis absorbs light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen.
example_tasks: Write the equation for photosynthesis: 6CO₂ + 6H₂O + light energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂.
Explain why photosynthesis is endothermic: it requires continuous input of light energy from the sun.
Describe how plants store absorbed light energy as chemical energy in glucose molecules.

sub_topics.name: Energy Diagrams for Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Drawing and interpreting diagrams that show energy increasing from reactants to products.
example_tasks: Draw an energy diagram for an endothermic reaction showing that products have higher energy than reactants, with energy absorbed from surroundings.
Label the activation energy and the energy absorbed on an endothermic reaction diagram.
Explain why the energy level of products is higher than reactants in endothermic reactions: energy has been absorbed from the surroundings.

sub_topics.name: Applications of Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical uses of endothermic reactions in technology and daily life.
example_tasks: Describe how instant cold packs use endothermic dissolution of ammonium nitrate in water to provide cooling for injuries.
Explain how evaporative cooling (an endothermic process) is used in swamp coolers and why sweating cools your body.
Research how thermal decomposition (endothermic) is used industrially to break down limestone (CaCO₃) into quicklime (CaO) and CO₂.

sub_topics.name: Measuring Energy Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to measure and calculate temperature changes associated with chemical reactions.

sub_topics.name: Temperature vs. Heat
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between temperature (average kinetic energy) and heat (thermal energy transferred).
example_tasks: Explain the difference between temperature (measure of average kinetic energy of particles) and heat (energy transferred due to temperature difference).
Describe why a large pot of warm water can contain more thermal energy than a small cup of boiling water.
Give examples showing that heat flows from higher temperature to lower temperature objects.

sub_topics.name: Using Thermometers
sub_topics.short_description: Practicing proper techniques for measuring temperature changes during reactions.
example_tasks: Measure and record the initial temperature of water, add a substance that dissolves endothermically, and measure the final temperature to calculate the temperature change.
Explain why thermometers should be stirred gently and read at eye level for accurate measurements.
Design an experiment to compare the temperature changes of different exothermic reactions using consistent measurement techniques.

sub_topics.name: Calculating Temperature Change
sub_topics.short_description: Computing the temperature change (ΔT) as final temperature minus initial temperature.
example_tasks: Calculate ΔT if initial temperature is 22°C and final temperature is 35°C: ΔT = 35 - 22 = 13°C.
Determine whether a reaction is exothermic or endothermic given: Ti = 20°C, Tf = 15°C (endothermic, ΔT = -5°C).
Create a data table to record initial and final temperatures for multiple trials and calculate average temperature change.

sub_topics.name: Calorimetry Introduction
sub_topics.short_description: Basic introduction to measuring heat energy changes using simple calorimeters.
example_tasks: Build a simple calorimeter using nested foam cups and a thermometer to measure heat released by a reaction.
Explain why calorimeters are insulated: to minimize heat exchange with the surroundings so measured temperature change reflects only the reaction.
Conduct an experiment burning a food item under a can of water and calculate the temperature increase to estimate the food's energy content.

sub_topics.name: Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn that reactions require initial energy input to break bonds and start the reaction, even if the overall process is exothermic.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that activation energy is the minimum energy needed to initiate a chemical reaction.
example_tasks: Explain why a match must be struck (providing activation energy) before it will burn, even though combustion releases energy overall.
Define activation energy as the energy barrier that must be overcome for reactants to transform into products.
Draw an energy diagram showing the activation energy as the 'hill' that reactants must climb before forming products.

sub_topics.name: Catalysts
sub_topics.short_description: Learning that catalysts lower activation energy, allowing reactions to proceed faster without being consumed.
example_tasks: Observe hydrogen peroxide decomposing slowly, then rapidly when manganese dioxide catalyst is added, demonstrating how catalysts speed reactions.
Explain why catalysts are not consumed in reactions: they provide an alternative pathway with lower activation energy but are regenerated.
Give examples of catalysts in everyday life: enzymes in digestion, catalytic converters in cars, yeast in bread making.

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how temperature, concentration, and surface area affect whether particles have enough energy to overcome activation energy.
example_tasks: Explain why increasing temperature speeds up reactions: more particles have kinetic energy exceeding the activation energy.
Describe how grinding a solid reactant into powder increases reaction rate by increasing surface area and collision frequency.
Investigate how concentration affects reaction rate: higher concentration means more frequent collisions, increasing likelihood of exceeding activation energy.

name: Temperature and Particle Motion
short_description: Students explore the relationship between temperature and the kinetic energy of particles, developing understanding of the kinetic molecular theory. This topic explains macroscopic temperature in terms of microscopic particle motion.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Molecular Theory
sub_topics.short_description: Learning the basic principles that explain the behavior of matter in terms of moving particles.

sub_topics.name: Matter Composed of Particles
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that all matter is made of tiny particles (atoms, molecules, ions) in constant motion.
example_tasks: Explain the kinetic molecular theory's main idea: all matter consists of particles in constant, random motion.
Describe evidence for particle motion: diffusion of food coloring in water, smell of perfume spreading through a room.
